query: When managing pastureland for natural pest control, is it better to delay mowing/grazing or to use grazing instead of cutting?
relevant_summary: Evidence on delaying mowing/first grazing shows mixed or neutral effects on natural enemies and pests: one replicated, randomised, controlled study found fewer predatory spiders with delayed cutting, several studies found no change in insect predator numbers, ant diversity decreased in one study, and pests increased in one of two studies while the other found no effect; other insect groups were sometimes lower, sometimes mixed, or unchanged [727]. Broader biodiversity responses to delaying mowing/grazing included more insect species visiting flowers and greater abundance of some spiders and ground beetles in some studies, while other studies found no clear effect on some insects and spiders [131]. Evidence on using grazing instead of cutting also shows mixed or neutral effects: two studies reported mixed effects on natural enemies across species and dates and one found no effect; across five studies on pests, one found more pests, two found variable effects depending on pest group/date, and two found no effect; one study found no effect on disease when grazing was used in addition to cutting [885].

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "pastureland pest control delay mowing grazing use grazing instead of cutting natural enemies parasitism beetles", "k": 3, "offset": 0}
{"action_id":"727"}
{"action_id":"885"}

query: What are the overall effects of altering pesticide application strategies to benefit natural enemies?
relevant_summary: Altering application strategies can increase natural enemies but with mixed outcomes for pests, crop damage, yields, and economics: Earlier-season insecticide sprays increased natural enemies in one controlled study, while pest and disease outcomes were mixed (some reductions, some no effect), yields were mixed or unchanged except for higher yields when applied at suspected crop susceptibility, and profits were higher with similar costs when timed to suspected susceptibility (723). Threshold-based spraying increased natural enemies in two of three years but effects were short-lived; pest control was satisfactory in some studies but similar or inadequate in others; crop damage was usually similar to conventional programs though sometimes higher or slightly lower than unsprayed controls; yields were similar or mixed; profits were generally similar or variable across sites and years; and fewer applications were needed with potential for lower production costs (750). Delaying herbicide applications increased some natural enemy groups (especially later in the season) but also increased weeds; insect pest responses were mixed (some increases, some decreases depending on experiment and variety), crop damage was sometimes lower, and yields were lower in one study and unchanged in another (774).

query: When planting non-crop vegetation to enhance natural pest control, what is the comparative evidence for planting new hedges versus plants that attract natural enemies with chemicals?
relevant_summary: Plants that produce chemicals attractive to natural enemies: Across four studies from China, Germany, India and Kenya, three (including one replicated, randomised, controlled trial) found higher numbers of natural enemies where attractive plants were grown, and one study found the plant was attractive in lab tests; all four studies reported decreased pest populations or damage, and one replicated, randomised, controlled study reported increased crop yield (724). Planting new hedges: One randomised, replicated, controlled study from China found no effect on spiders in crops; one of two studies from France and China found more natural enemies in a hedge than in adjacent crops while the other found effects varied by crop type, hedge species and year; two randomised, replicated, controlled studies from France and Kenya found that natural enemy abundance in hedges depended on the shrub/tree species planted and varied between enemy groups; one randomised, replicated, controlled study from Kenya found that effects on nematodes in fallow plots varied between nematode groups (752).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"non-crop vegetation enhance natural pest control comparative evidence hedges vs plants that attract natural enemies with chemicals", "k": 3, "offset": 0}
{"action_id":"724"}
{"action_id":"754"}
{"action_id":"752"}

query: What are the potential negative impacts on crops when incorporating plant remains into the soil to control weeds?
relevant_summary: Two of three studies reported that incorporating allelopathic plant remains inhibited crop growth, with effects influenced by timing of application (728). Across randomized, replicated, controlled studies, yield responses were variable, including negative yield effects in some comparisons with weeded controls (728).

{"action_id":"910"}
tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "910",
  "action_title": "Amend the soil with fresh plant material or crop remains",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Biodiversity: One randomized, replicated experiment from Belgium found increased microbial biomass when crop remains and straw were added.
Compaction: One study from India found improved soil structure when straw was incorporated. One before-and-after trial from the UK found that incorporating straw residues by discing (reduced tillage) did not improve anaerobic soils (low oxygen levels) in compacted soils.
Erosion: Two randomized, replicated studies from Canada and India measured the effect of incorporating straw on erosion. One found straw addition reduced soil loss, and one found mixed effects depending on soil type.
Nutrient loss: Four replicated studies from Belgium, the UK and the USA (one also controlled, one also randomized, and two also controlled and randomized) reported higher soil nitrogen levels when compost or straw was applied, but mixed results when processed wastes were added. One also found reduced nitrate leaching when straw was incorporated. One replicated study from China and the Philippines found mixed results depending on site.
Soil organic carbon: Six studies from China, Denmark and India measured the effect of incorporating plant material into the soil. All (including one replicated, two randomized, replicated studies, one controlled, randomized, replicated studies and one controlled before-and-after site comparison) found higher carbon levels when plant material was added. One found higher carbon levels when straw was applied along with NPK fertilizers. One also found larger soil aggregates. One replicated study from China and the Philippines found mixed results depending on site.
Yield: One replicated trial from Denmark found higher barley yield when straw was incorporated. One trial from the Philippines found higher grain yields when crop remains were incorporated earlier in the season.
 
Soil types covered: clay, clay loam, fine loam, loam/sandy loam, loamy sand, sandy, sandy clay loam, sandy loam, sandy-silt, silt loam, silty, silty-clay."
}
